awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Tabletop High-Resolution Scanning Electron Microscope
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description
This Major Research Instrumentation project supports the acquisition of a tabletop high-resolution scanning electron microscope at York College of the City University of New York (York College/CUNY). The acquired scanning electron microscope is used in a wide range of fields including chemistry, geology, environmental science, and pharmaceutical science; it enables the training of undergraduate and master's students in the fundamental principles of scanning electron microscopy, and enhances the curriculum activities for pre-service teachers by providing them with advanced skills and curriculum content. The tabletop scanning electron microscope is also part of a substantial growth plan for a new Master's program at York College and a key instrument for expanding and improving research and training activities that are highly beneficial for York College students in the science disciplines. 

Technical Description
The tabletop high-resolution scanning electron microscope enables compositional and topographical analysis of metals, nanoparticles, pharmaceutical materials, and biomaterials. It is used in multidisciplinary research projects such as 1) elucidation of the crystallization processes of materials, 2) investigation of metal contamination in aquifers, 3) elucidation of molecular mechanisms of amyloid formation from mutant peptides, and 4) study of the anti-inflammatory and pro-inflammatory effects of nanoparticles in their interactions with biological systems. The instrument can perform at a 1-30 kV accelerating voltage range; it is equipped with backscatter and secondary electron detectors, an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer, and a variable aperture that can provide a similar resolution to some full-size systems. The low costs of maintenance, the modest infrastructural requirements, and the excellent ease-of-use make the instrument a convenient and versatile analytical tool for York College faculty members and other researchers, who mostly rely on undergraduate students for their research projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF MRI award has provided the STEM departments of York College with the capability to gain compositional and high-resolution topographical information for a wide range of materials. The full-size Zeiss EVO-10 scanning electron microscope (SEM) acquired with this award is housed in the Department of Chemistry of York College. In addition to the backscatter and secondary electron detectors, the instrument is also equipped with a dispersive X-ray spectrometer for elemental analysis of sample surfaces.  This versatile instrument is also available for outside users that are interested in the morphological and compositional characterization of solid materials, and a sputter coater for the analysis of non-conductive materials has been made accessible to all the SEM users.

The acquired SEM has addressed a critical need at York College. Researchers from the Department of Chemistry and the Department of Earth and Physical Sciences have benefitted from the instrument capabilities to perform structural and compositional characterization of ultra-small objects that was not otherwise possible. Some of the research projects that profited from the instrument are the study of crystallization processes of amorphous pharmaceutical solids, the characterization of aquifer sediments and soils, the characterization of the surface properties of components for a Mu2e straw tube drift chamber, and the morphological analysis of amyloid fibrils from mutant peptides as potential treatment for type-2 diabetes. Several undergraduate, master, and Ph.D. students who were involved in these projects have been trained in the use of scanning electron microscopy, which is a central analytical technique in the materials science.

The funded instrument has also contributed to the development of educational activities and enabled the permanent incorporation of a high-resolution module with a hands-on component into a master-level laboratory course. Similar modules will be incorporated in existing undergraduate courses. Experience with this advanced instrumentation will allow young scientists to develop analytical skills, understand the limitations of the instrument, and acquire a sense for the significance and value of their data. Such experiences will better prepare the York College undergraduate and graduate students for professional employment.
